description: The length of time the customer has been with the company, as long-term customers are less likely to churn.
The amount the customer is billed each month, as higher charges may lead to churn.
The frequency and satisfaction of the customer's interactions with customer support, as positive experiences may reduce churn.
Whether the customer has a fixed-term contract or a month-to-month arrangement, as contract type can impact churn rates.
How frequently and extensively the customer uses the company's products or services, as more usage may indicate lower churn likelihood.
The presence of competitive offers or promotions from rival companies, as these can influence customer churn.
Any problems related to billing or payment processing, as these can contribute to customer dissatisfaction and potential churn.
The feedback provided by the customer through surveys or reviews, as negative feedback may indicate a higher likelihood of churn.
Significant life events or changes that may impact the customer's need for the company's services, as these events can influence churn.
The reliability and consistency of the company's services, as service interruptions or issues can lead to customer dissatisfaction and churn.
